title: How to Make a Wax Paper Doll

steps.headline: Select an image of a face from either a magazine, clip art, or a copy of a photo.
steps.description: Size is not crucial because there is nothing realistic about these dolls, but it should be large enough to see easily--at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) or more.

steps.headline: Cut off the flat bottom of a paper lunch bag.
steps.description: Cut out the seam that runs down the back

steps.headline: Spread the piece of paper out flat and fold in half vertically.
Glue the face to the front of the sack which is the top layer.
steps.description: Position it in the middle of the top third of the bag. This will leave room for you to add a crown, a headdress, or some such ridiculous item.

steps.headline: Draw the above-mentioned headdress.
steps.description: This could be the hair, a hat, a crown or whatever you like above the face.

steps.headline: Give the face a neck and a body of sorts.
steps.description: The body lines down the sides should be at least 4 inches (10.2 cm) or more apart. They can be straight or curved but should go all the way to the bottom of the bag.

steps.headline: Go over the pencil lines with a permanent black pen.
Decorate your doll.
steps.description: Draw straight or squiggly lines; add geometric shapes and any desired decoration. You can also stamp images or words, and/or add stickers, beads, etc.

steps.headline: Hold the doll together.
steps.description: Place a few short lengths of double-stick tape inside the doll to hold it together; then cut out around it, leaving at least a 1-inch border all the way around.

steps.headline: Stitch the doll.
steps.description: Making sure that the paper is still taped to hold the bag together, stitch around the doll--preferably on a sewing machine. Stitch on or very close to the drawn lines. Do not stitch across the bottom. A contrasting color thread is suggested when stitching the doll.

steps.headline: Cut away the excess paper.
steps.description: Cut about ⁄8 or ⁄4 inch (0.3 or 0.6 cm) outside the stitched lines. Cut across the bottom to make it straight. If desired, decorate the back of your doll.

steps.headline: Melt the wax.
steps.description: In an electric skillet. Melt the beeswax to 200 F degrees. You can also use a double-boiler filled with the wax. Make yourself a holder from aluminum foil by tearing off a length of the foil, scrunching it up, and rolling it until you have a sturdy stick. Bend it up about 10 inches (25.4 cm) from one end.

steps.headline: Dip the doll in the wax.
steps.description: Insert the long end into the doll. Hold the shorter end in your hand and dip the doll in the wax. Make certain that the doll is completely covered on both sides with the wax. Hold it over the wax to let any excess drip off; then stand her up to dry completely. If you're using a double-boiler, you will dip your doll in the wax using tongs. If there are any white spots where there is a build-up of the wax, use a heat gun to melt off the surplus.

steps.headline: Enjoy your doll!
steps.description: Once you have made one of these dolls, you will see how really easy they are to make and what fun they can be. You can make a bunch to use as table favors, place cards, on sticks as a centerpiece, a grouping for a temporary "art piece" or use longer bags to make wine bottle covers.
